intro: Paepalanthus saxicola var. pilosus, commonly known as the hairy rock cactus, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in regions of Argentina and Chile. It is a member of the Cactaceae family and is characterized by its compact, spiny stems that are often covered in a dense layer of white, woolly hairs. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in late summer, typically in clusters at the ends of the stems. It thrives in rocky, arid environments and is adapted to withstand extreme temperatures and limited water availability. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens for its ornamental value.
